course.subject: LIFS
course.name: Microbiology
course.description: Classification, identification, structure, physiology, and genetics of microorganisms; importance of microorganisms in health, environment, and biotechnology.
course.corequisites: LIFS 2040 OR LIFS 2060

reviews.author: 石頭
reviews.title: it should be called pathogen biology after midterm
reviews.comment_content:
before mid term was
1.bacteria
2.bact classification
3.bacterial growth
4.eukaryotic microbes
5.virus
baisicly the different kinds of microorganisms and their properties with classifications

after midterm
6.human microbe interactions
7.controlling microorganism in the environment
8.antimicrobial medications
9.immunity
10pathogenesis1
11pathogenesis 2
12 identifications of pathogens 1
13 identifications of pathogens 2
14 epidemiological methods
15 emerging diseases and food microorganisms

well, content before midterm is like normal biology in a more specific field
after midterm it suddenly became all about illnesses, why and how they happen, how to identify,avoid and control with specific methods and drugs, ect.
and i think it should be called pathogenic biology instead
reviews.comment_teaching:
banfield teaches the mid term and as usual, quite mean and grumpy, but i think we are used to it. despite that, i like his teaching and presentation, making the concepts clear with good ppt(as long as you attend course).

Tang teaches after the midterm, its my first time in her course and it felt subjectively terrible.
i personally felt her verbal speed is very slow, but somehow manage to talk finish 80 pages in one lecture, she spent quite some time on the concepts, but fail to make ppl (at least me) understand. the ppt is ok if you attend the lecture and take notes, though might need some time to decode what she meant .i recommend google/youtube the keywords directly, it saved me tonnes of time .
reviews.comment_grading:
i wrote this right after the final so i dont know yet

ppl say that the mean for the course is quite high, probably because the midterm is easy( i did well) and the final is just remembering things. i dont think i will have a good grade because i dont like remembering things

tips for finals
1. remember all the names and detailed properties,mechanisms of the microbes
2.remember what and how specific and non-specific  drugs are used to treat them
3. remember the specific differentiation/ identification test for the specific microbes
4. be aware of anything related to gram +/-
5. understand the immune system throughoutly especially the names of the immune cell response
6. remember every case study, especially the name of pathogen that appears

if you can do well on the things above, you can get a good grade,
if you have time and hesitating whether or not to remember something, just remember it

PS. all the exams are mcq, so you can just remember the initial letter of a name/method and relate it , it saves storage
reviews.comment_workload:
as you can see in the content above, there is 5 ppt (~50pages)for midterm
and 10ppt (~60pages)for finals
recommend to revise for final at least 1 wk before if you never attended class, many things to remember.

most things are straight facts like wt drug is used to treat wt disease, and trivia that i think most ppl wont be interested like the name of bacteria in your intestine that keeps you slim.

these knowledge make up 60% of what you have to know and it felt disgusting to remember them all. i just dont feel satisfied by learning these knowledge, thus low motive to remember them.

things for midterm is fine, like normal
and there is no homework too

reviews.author: royalmilktea
reviews.title: Banfield is one fair instructor. Harsh, but fair.
reviews.comment_content:
Basically everything you would ever want to know about microbiology
and... things you might not want to know as well
like all the defining features of microbes
the diseases (with photos) associated with them
the antimicrobial drugs
how to make cheese
etc

Very helpful if you want to learn how microbes play a role in public health or in... daily life, really. Banfield tries to make the course relatable to general citizens (as shown by the extra slides that tell you what the chapter will teach general citizens). He puts special emphasis on how the microbes interact with you.

For detailed listing see attachment
reviews.comment_teaching:
Oh Prof. Banfield... I guess his teaching style is just very controversial.
Some people may say he's very mean and vengeful because of what they did to him (and how he responded) in Fall 14/15 Cell Biology. But like, if you're a decent human being, you'll think he's a fair and predictable person that won't take your bullshit. Is he sarcastic? Yes. But is he fair in his teaching, exam question setting and in his character? Yes (his exam questions aren't easy, but if you studied you'd do decently well -- there are always a few questions that come out of nowhere but that's just him trying to distinguish between the top students; nothing to do with the general crowd since no one can get the questions anyway and so the curve is just skewed lower).
To me, his sarcasm does not really deter me in an academic setting. I think it's his way of being an interesting human being (versus a boring, reading off the slides professor that you'll hate a lot more). Prof. Banfield is a typical Canadian -- funny and sarcastic (and he does like to make fun of his American "friends down South"). And in class, his character can translate into a lot of jokes and a less boring lecture. Not sure if the jokes are intentional, but his character definitely makes me enjoy class a lot more.
If you have questions/issues, you can definitely email him or ask him after class. He really cares about his students and tries as much as he can to help if they have problems. I've emailed him about a lot of issues and he kindly helped me through all of them.
If you want to talk about your exams, you can also just email him and set up a time. He'll be happy to talk about what you did wrong and how you can improve.
(side note: I guess that's why he was so angry about the Fall 14/15 incident anyway. If you have a problem, he would be happy to discuss it with you. That's how he functions. You don't bitch about him behind his back.)

Jessica is pretty normal as everyone says... Teaches to the slide, gives relatively easy, straight-off-lecture-slides exam questions. Her LearnSmart assignments were also a lot lighter compared to Banfield's.
Jessica is very approachable if you have questions. She's such a sweetie pie.
reviews.comment_grading:
With the LearnSmart, the class grade actually improved a lot this year, I heard.
I personally got an unexpectedly high grade that could not be predicted by my midterm and final scores.
reviews.comment_workload: He tried out an extra thing this year for extra credit, "LearnSmart" -- a few hundred questions per week or so to test your understanding on the material (you'll have to buy LearnSmart and do 100% of it to get the extra credit, and you can also choose to buy the ebook on top of it. The ebook is recommended since it really helps you answer the questions). It's legit "extra credit" that he adds AFTER he gives out the initial grades though, so you don't get penalized if you don't do it (but in the future he said he'll try to make it a legit assignment for the class; good luck poor kids)... A ridiculous amount of work? Yes. Helpful though? Also yes. It's very likely that he will cut the workload when he makes it a legit class assignment to cater to all students (not only the hard-working ones). He did say that he had to make the extra credit thing a lot more extra work to warrant extra credit, so hopefully he'll cut down on LearnSmart content if he's counting them for the actual grade? I guess we'll find out this year.

reviews.author: SomeGirl
reviews.comment_content:
Introduction to microbiology, Bacteria, Fungi/Protists and Viruses are taught by Banfield.

All the other intensive topics are taught by Jessica.
reviews.comment_teaching:
First nine lectures are taught by Banfield. The rest 14 lectures are taught by Jessica.

Banfield's teaching is interactive and interesting with little content on the slides. If you talk a lot during class, you might embarass yourself in front of the whole lecture theatre. If you leave in the middle of the lecture, he will make fun of you. So, you better think before you act.

Jessica's teaching covers every point on the slide which can get boring and confusing.
reviews.comment_grading:
Banfield's part for midterm is very light. Jessica's part has tons of information on the slide to remember. If you don't attend her classes, it's perfectly alright.

One midterm (40%) and one final exam (60%). All MCs.

The mean is very high around 75% for midterm. However, for final exam, the mean was around 80%. To get an A, you should aim for around 90%.
reviews.comment_workload:
You need to spend time going through the materials before exams. Cramming might not be the best case-scenario.

If you are good at memorization, this is the course for you.

reviews.author: Daniel's
reviews.title: Heavy memorisation; little understanding of mechanisms
reviews.comment_content:
Content from Prof. Bandfield is mostly about the characteristic of Bacteria, with some content about Fungi, Virus and Protozoa.
The content seems to be learnt bit by bit in other courses , so to me it's not that difficult. But I still find the Mid-Term questions rather complicated, and not that straight forward

Content from Dr. Tang are mostly about pathogens how they affect our body, how our body response to it, and how to remove it. I do find the content rather interesting and relatable to daily life. It is not the very theoretical microbiology content if that's what you are expecting. To me there are a lot of memorisation of facts, not that much understanding of complex mechanisms involved. Usually the mechanisms are briefly mentioned only
reviews.comment_teaching:
Prof. Banfield
Teaching style similar to cell biology, ppt also organised the same. not much to add.

Dr. Tang
Again as always huge amount of content to memorise, the ppt itself is very detail and would take you weeks (not days) to read through them and recite.
The class are somewhat interesting, Dr. Tang do sometimes try to add some more fun facts to the ppt, and give explanation to image that are not self-explanatory,
But if you would want to sleep for 1.5hr more, I would say only reading the ppt should also be fine.
reviews.comment_grading:
Dunno yet

Mid Term
all MC
Close Book

Final
90Q/ 90min
Close Book
All MC 4/5 choice per question
very typical MC exam in HKUST LIFS.
reviews.comment_workload:
As always only Mid-Term, Final.
But huge amount of content to memorise especially for Final

Mid-Term the content are relatively less, but the questions are more difficult. So one would still need to spend time throughly understand all the content.

As for Final, over 600 pages of ppt to memorise, and almost all little ting within the ppt would be examined. If you are wondering, you do need to memorise the following:
1. All the orange vocabs and it defintion.
2. All the bacteria species/ disease/ effect/ method to eliminate and everything related to it.
3. All biochemical test / agar/ whatever tests and how to interpretative.
4. All the equations and how they differ.
or just remember everything you can.

And do start early for revision, try your best to memorise some parts after the lecture is delivered. As a reference, I don't consider myself to have good memory, and 10 days is not enough for me to remember all the content.

Good luck to you all.

reviews.comment_teaching:
Normal

Recommend attending Dr. Tang's lecture as she, sometimes, has pop-up questions during the lecture. Even though those questions will not carry any credits to your final grade, some of those questions are quite similar to those MCQ appear in the final exam
reviews.comment_grading:
Normal Grading Policy

40% midterm(80 MCQ in 80 mins)
60% Final(100 MCQ in 90 mins)

My score
Midterm: 69/80 Highest 72
Final: Not Disclosed

Letter Grade: A

For Jessica's Part, the final exam consisted of multiple and single MCQs which requires thorough understanding of some of the key concepts and techniques.

Questions that will likely be asked in Banfield's Midterm:
What is the cell wall composition for Archea?
Which cellular structure enables microbiologists to differentiate Gram-positive and Gram-negative bacteria?
What techniques can be used to count the number of microorganisms in a culture?
Candle jars are used to culture what microorganisms under what conditions?
The growth pattern of obligate anaerobe in a test tube

Questions that will likely be asked in Dr. Tang's Final:
What bacteria can be found on the skin that are not pathogenic?
The sequence of workflow in next-generation sequencing
What gut microbiota will be dominant in slim and lean people's guts?
Defensin is similar to what antimicrobial agent?
Can neutrophils be stained with eosin?
The concept of MIC and MLC
What are the dominant bacteria in breast-feed milk?
reviews.comment_workload:
Light workload for Banfield's part
Huge workload for Dr.Tang's part, but still manageable if you study the ppt from Tang every day

reviews.comment_teaching:
Prof Banfield's teaching is quite funny but he made too much jokes and couldn't finished the course schedule so the course a bit rush in the end of his teaching part. Although he is a native speaker of English , he uses a lot examples to explain some difficult concept or term and he is willing to answer student questions in the chat box. As many time was spent in joking and answering student question ;) so the course content is not much in Prof Banfield's part and the midterm content is fine to review.

Dr Tang's teaching is also good and her English is pretty fluent. There are some fill in the blank questions at the beginning of each lesson for reviewing previous lesson. I think that's quite useful. But her teaching is sticking to course schedule so the content for final exam is quite heavy and there's many slides in one ppt so don't take it easy for revision.
reviews.comment_grading:
I don't know how they exactly giving the grade.
My mid term score is 64 out of 80 and the final grade is unknown. The mean is also unknown for this course but I got B+ finally. so I think if you study hard even you don't obtain a very high mark but you can still get a good grade.
reviews.comment_workload: only have one midterm and one final exam. they are both MCQ so the workload is light. Pay attention in the lesson and do the revision early you would be fine in this course. Remember the specific bacteria and virus name is important for Dr Tang's final exam. Good luck!

reviews.author: Metal_816
reviews.comment_content: Intensive and wide course, it touched upon a lot of important topics related to microbiology. Most of the topics were very detailed, each lecture had 80-120 slides. A lot of information to process, its a little overwhelming.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Professor Banfield was excellent, one of the best lecturers I've had so far. Very engaging and enjoyable lectures.
After the midterm we had Professor Tang who was great as well, but not as engaging as the previous lecturer.
Overall, the teach was great for the amount of information the course had.
reviews.comment_grading: Grading was good, the mean was around 60% for the midterm but around 50% for the finals. If you read through and know your content its good enough to get an A. Attending the lectures was not necessary since the power points had quite a bit of detail on them.
reviews.comment_workload:
There were no assignments, only a midterm and a final. The midterm was far easier than the final. Going to the lectures was useful for understanding certain processes, however the lecture notes are more than enough to get an A. There is a lot of information however, I spent about 2-3 hours understanding and going through each lecture for the amount of info in them.
I suggest start studying for the tests at least 2 weeks in advance.
